question.content:
Sasha tried to define a reflection across line $\ell$.

- Any point $Q$ on line of reflection $\ell$ maps to itself.
- Any point $P$ not on $\ell$ maps to a point $P'$ such that $P$ and $P'$ are the same distance from $\ell$.

**Which counterexample shows that Sasha's definition does not fully define a reflection?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This is a reflection and also matches Sasha's definition. It is not a counter-example.
choices.content: ![An unlabeled point and point Q are on line l. Point P is the same point for P prime. Line l is perpendicular to segment P P prime. The unlabeled point is the midpoint of line segment P P prime. Line segment P and unlabeled point and line segment P prime and unlabeled point P prime are congruent.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b221234b32929060cb4e3a46117fd2dd4b48814d)

choices.clue: This matches Sasha's definition, but is not a reflection, because $PP'$ is not perpendicular to $\ell$, and because both $P$ and $P'$ are on the same side of $\ell$.

Next to it is segment P prime also on the same upper side of line l. Both segments connect to unknown points on line l.  Line segment P and unlabeled point and line segment P prime and unlabeled point P prime are congruent.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9dd35974a23e4e74b6359d974b4a98e4873b0647)

![An unlabeled point and point Q are on line l. Point P is the same point for P prime. Line l is perpendicular to segment P P prime. The unlabeled point is not the midpoint of line segment P P prime. Line segment P and unlabeled point and line segment P prime and unlabeled point P prime are not congruent.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/72e50ac559c44faa03982fe79caaa2db7989aedf)
choices.clue: This is not a reflection and does not match Sasha's definition. It is not a counter-example.

Sasha's definition is incomplete because the line of reflection must be perpendicular to $\overline{PP'}$ where both $P$ and $P'$ are on the different sides of $\ell$. The counter-example matches Sasha's definition but is *not* a reflection.

hints.content:
A **counterexample** is an exception that proves a proposed rule or definition wrong. 

So our counterexample could be either of the following:

- An example of a reflection that does not match Sasha's definition
- An example of a figure that matches Sasha's definition, but is not a reflection

It only takes one counterexample to show that the proposed definition has a mistake or is incomplete.

This matches Sasha's definition, but is not a reflection, because $PP'$ is not perpendicular to $\ell$, and because both $P$ and $P'$ are on the same side of $\ell$.


[[☃ image 1]]

So it is a counterexample disproving Sasha's definition.

options.alt: An unlabeled point and point Q are on line l. Point Q is the same point for Q prime. Line l is perpendicular to segment P on its upper is upper side. Next to it is segment P prime also on the same upper side of line l. Both segments connect to unknown points on line l.  Line segment P and unlabeled point and line segment P prime and unlabeled point P prime are congruent.
